awd_titl_txt: Laboratory Technician Support: Experimental Hydrogeophysics Technician
awd_abstract_narration:
This award establishes a technician in the Hydrogeophysics Laboratory at the University of Wyoming.  The purpose of this technician is to provide a novel link between broad Earth science research and quantitative geophysical measurement to understand Earth processes experimentally, and to assist in training students and scientists. Revealing properties and processes about the near-subsurface environment - deeper than can be accessed with manual probes, in multiple space and/or time dimensions - is important to promoting the progress of environmental geoscience. Hydrogeophysics encompasses the observation and measurement of hydrologic processes and anomalies from the Earth's surface to the depth of the deepest groundwater that is connected to modern hydrologic systems. Research enabled by this diverse set of geophysical methods spans much of Earth science: glaciology, sedimentology, hydrology, ecology, and others. This award enables a range of scientists across the country to access resources of the Hydrogeophysics Laboratory and related measurement expertise. 

The core mission of this project is to provide an experimental hydrogeophysical technician at the University of Wyoming who serves the broad geoscience community in support of experimental hydrogeophysical research. The objectives are to: 1) enable a broad range of scientists to benefit from hydrogeophysical measurements, 2) provide instrument and methodology training, 3) contribute to methodological advancements, and 4) enhance outreach. The technician performs measurements and assists visitors in using or designing experimental apparatus, and with sample preparation. The technician focuses on ground penetrating radar, electrical resistivity, and nuclear magnetic geophysical methods. In the lab, primary efforts are directed towards supporting experimental research and material property calibrations. Experimental hydrogeophysics work is also conducted outside the brick-and-mortar lab, and therefore the technician also provides support to related field experiments, particularly related to acquiring samples and ancillary measurements needed to develop material property transform functions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the salary of a laboratory technician who managed the University of Wyoming Hydrogeophysics Lab for five years.

The Paul Heller Hydrogeophysics Lab focuses on geophysical characterization of unconsolidated porous material with specific focus on physical properties related to water storage and flow. This is accomplished through measurements and experimental work using direct-current electrical geophysics, dielectric measurements with high-frequency radar, and nuclear magnetic resonance scanning.

Laboratory operations require a thorough understanding of experimental procedures, safety, and instrument operation that demands expert full-time technical staff. To this end, the laboratory technician position was envisioned to: 1) provide prompt, standardized training to student and external users to enable a broader range of users to access the lab, 2) enable enhanced instrument maintenance to maximize up-time, 3) permit fabrication of experimental apparatus, 4) assist with field sample acquisition to facility seamless follow-on lab analyses and 5) oversee all safety and regulatory aspects of lab operation to ensure compliance with University guidelines.   

Accomplishments of the laboratory technician during support from this award included: 1) maintenance of lab instruments, 2) supporting field interpretations with laboratory calibrations, 3) assembling and testing of a cryogenic apparatus to supplement the nuclear magnetic resonance instrument present in the lab, 4) preparation of training materials to enable more users to use the lab, 5) development of teaching materials, particularly to support courses during the pandemic, and  6) establishing new magnetic sample evaluation instrumentation and procedures.

 

Intellectual Merit:

  • Supported research that led to the publication of a PhD-student led paper and dissertation chapter of a on methane release from permafrost.
  • Supported research that led to the publication of a PhD-student led paper and dissertation chapter of operation of nuclear magnetic resonance instrumentation.
  • Developed and tested a novel cryogenic nuclear magnetic resonance apparatus capable of mainlining samples sub-freezing during measurement.
  • Created and curated datasets through publicly accessible databases.

 

Broader Impacts:

Supporting projects outside the department and university:  While members of the University of Wyoming community benefitted from the support and expertise of the technician, importantly, there was a consistent trend towards supporting fewer internal projects as time progressed, from 35% effort during the first year to less than 10% effort by the final year reflecting a shift to prioritize external users.  This is consistent with the overall increasing trend of effort over time to supporting external projects with the desirable outcome of making resources in the lab more accessible and useful to students and investigators. 

Training graduate, undergraduate, and external users: In general, teaching and training time allocation remained approximately stable at about 10% effort per year throughout the life of the project. These activities included preparation of materials to support courses, writing standard operating procedure documentation, and hands-on training, particularly with undergraduate and graduate students who needed to use instrumentation in the lab to support their research. After the award the technicians’ position has been maintained, though they have taken a higher-level role in the department with management responsibilities across multiple facilities.

Modified by: Andrew Parsekian
